	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

You probably meant to reply to the group.

2616 leaves enough room to debat=
e here. My key point is that the  
symmetry is not a requirement, but it ma=
y be nice to have it in  
certain classes of applications.

Subbu


>
>
> Y=
es, entities have content types too, but one key difference is that  
> rep=
resentations are usually negotiable (through content- 
> negotiation), wher=
e as the data that a client is POSTing or PUTting  
> is not. See 2616#1.3.=

>
> 2621-7, =93Request and Response messages may transfer an entity [...]
=
>
> So in both instances, whatever you pass around or return is an entity.
=
>
> As for 2616-10.4.6, =93The resource identified by the request is only  =

> capable of generating response entities which have content  
> character=
istics not acceptable according to the accept headers sent  
> in the reque=
st.=94
>
> I understand this one as meaning the response entity has content=
  
> characteristics. As you quite rightly say, so does the request  
> ent=
ity (the content).
>
> If I understand you correctly, you are saying that t=
he specification  
> applies the term resource to an entity that has been s=
erialized in a  
> type / language / encoding that has been negotiated, whe=
reas an  
> entity that is a serialization with a type / language / encodin=
g  
> that has not been negotiated is not a representation of a resource  
=
> but an entity?
>
> You=92re accurate in your reading of the terminology s=
ection, and of  
> course about the lack of content negotiation in a quest.=
 I=92ll  
> personally consider that the request entity you send in a reque=
st  
> body in a certain content type / language / encoding is as much a  
=
> representation of a resource as is the requested entity returned in  
> a=
 response with a content-type, negotiated with an accept or not.
>
> The on=
ly missing bit is to add an Accept: header to a 415:  
> Unsupported media =
type and you have client negociation on a resource.
>
> The way I see thing=
s is that a resource can be represented in a  
> multitude of ways based on=
 type, language, etc. Waht gets sent back  
> is a representation of a reso=
urce, with metadata describing the  
> representation, and content formatte=
d in a certain way. When you  
> send a post or put, you provide content fo=
rmatted in a certain way,  
> with a language, a type, etc. This stuff is b=
y definition a subset  
> of what the resource is, but you decide how you d=
escribe your  
> resource without asking the server what it expects.
>
>
> =
Where does the symmetry requirement come from?
>
> Uniformity of access to =
a resource is a good thing. If I can PUT and  
> POST in json or in xml, I =
really expect to be able to GET in the  
> same content type. The other way=
 is not necessarily true of course.
>
> --
> SerialSeb
